repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

body:
Here‚Äôs a simpler reduced example, just showing the main polygon for Antarctica which appears to be the source of the problem. Generated from the 1:110M Natural Earth dataset.

[![screen shot 2014-03-22 at 1 16 08 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/2491820/d72cc82a-b1fe-11e3-9249-2531c58c3550.png)](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/61fc3a8681f88a6d72e1)

This was generated with TopoJSON using the default settings (and then capturing the resulting GeoJSON for the main Polygon). As before, --no-stitch-poles fixes the problem for the 1:50M dataset but not for 1:10M or 1:110M.
I think the problem here has something to do with the Lambert conic conformal projection extending to infinity at the bottom of the map.

rename.to: Winding order bug, again, with d3.geo.conicConformal.

rename.from: Winding order bug, again, with d3.geo.conicConformal.

body:
Even simpler example is that rendering {type: "Sphere"} ‚Äî¬†even with a clipExtent ‚Äî¬†using d3.geo.conicConformal fails.

[
![screen shot 2014-03-22 at 1 47 23 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/2491881/5ebca2d4-b203-11e3-9efb-b5aeb706fa50.png)
](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/94523316125d432d9dd3)

issue.title: Clamp latitude for conic conformal projection.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body: The Lambert conic conformal projection extends to infinity along the outer edge of the projection, and thus the latitude must be clamped either at -œÄ/2 or +œÄ/2 depending on the parallels. Fixes #1802.

body: All of these issues are fixed with #1804, except, for some reason, the pre-projected 1:10M dataset. However, projecting 1:10M in the browser works correctly, so perhaps it‚Äôs related to the lack of the double-precision adder in TopoJSON? Needs further investigation.

Proof (projecting 1:10M in the browser). :grinning: 

![screen shot 2014-03-22 at 5 28 12 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/2492321/129fe900-b222-11e3-9cc3-61ff473df78d.png)

I tested both the geo-rings fix and the adder fix in TopoJSON, and with either or both of these fixes applied, the pre-projected TopoJSON still has problems with Antarctica in the 1:10M dataset. But this is strange because with the d3.geo.conicConformal fix there‚Äôs no issue rendering it in the browser‚Ä¶

issue.title: If desired, stitch poles before projecting.

repository.name: topojson
repository.description: An extension of GeoJSON that encodes topology! üåê

issue.body: When a projection is specified, the topology is constructed in Cartesian coordinates after the projection is applied, so pole stitching is implicitly disabled. Instead, we must stitch poles before the projection is applied. This fixes the remaining issue in mbostock/d3#1802.

body:
And proof! Pre-projecting TopoJSON for the 1:10M works!

[![screen shot 2014-03-22 at 8 40 04 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/2492565/efb3ebec-b23c-11e3-8da7-d10d29f3faa1.png)](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/6d45b2f90a9b2b51add1/071d160e7ec74ff40f42bb486155469ab357f09b)

issue.title: Better fix for d3.geo.conicConformal.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
Rather than clamping latitudes to ¬±(œÄ/2 - Œµ), we preserve infinite coordinates and correct the issue where 0 \* Infinity resulted in NaN; instead we substitute 0, which appears to fix the problem in #1802.

Includes tests and a fix for the inverse projection.
